Name: Linear Programming
Description: Optimize a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints. The most fundamental and widely applied type.

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming
Description: An LP where some or all decision variables are constrained to be integers. Adds combinatorial complexity.
Solvability: NP-Hard in general. Solved with Branch & Bound
Example: Cutting Planes. Solution time can grow exponentially.

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: Minimizing a convex objective function over a convex set. A broad class that includes LPs
column8: etc.). Any local minimum is a global minimum.

Name: Quadratic Programming
Description: Optimize a quadratic objective function subject to linear constraints. A subclass of convex optimization.
Solvability: Efficiently solvable if the objective is convex (e.g.

Name: Non-Linear Programming
Description: Optimize a non-linear objective function subject to non-linear constraints. The most general form.
Solvability: Extremely difficult in general. Solvers often find local
Appearances: minima. Heavily dependent on problem structure.

Name: Constraint Programming
Description: A programming paradigm where relations between variables are stated in the form of constraints. Excellent for feasibility problems and highly combinatorial problems.
Example: constraint propagation. Strong for logical constraints.

Name: Stochastic Programming
Description: Optimization under uncertainty. Parameters are known only by their probability distributions. Models involve random variables.
Solvability: Computationally intensive. Often requires generating and solving many scenarios.
Appearances: supply chain management with uncertain costs.

Name: Robust Optimization
Description: A framework for optimization under uncertainty that seeks a solution that is feasible for all realizations of the data within a defined uncertainty set.
column9: Portfolio optimization to guard against worst-case market movements.

Name: Dynamic Programming
Description: A method for solving complex problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems. It is both a modeling framework and an algorithm.
Solvability: Solvability depends on the problem. Can suffer from the "curse of dimensionality".

Name: Multi-Objective Optimization
Description: Problems involving more than one objective function to be optimized simultaneously. There is no single optimal solution
Solvability: but a set of Pareto-optimal solutions.
Example: No single "solution". Goal is to find or approximate the Pareto frontier.
